comments:
When ever i start or restart Eclipse but haven't closed all editor tabs (doesn't matter if only one or one hundred are open) i get an error. Every time i have to close all editors, restart Eclipse and then start it again, and then re-open all the files i was viewing last time... I reinstall latest build of eclipse but problem persists.

The error is:

An Internal error occured during: "Initializing Java Tooling"

The package explorer reports:

Happens for me too, but seems to be avoidable by switching to e.g. the Outline view before quitting Eclipse; leaving the Package Explorer view selected on quit recreates this bug on startup every time. It is not necessary to close editor tabs.

"Initializing Java tooling" is slow (>30 seconds) when this bug has not been triggered, with only a small number of repositories, but 5 of those are remote; my feeling is that this is something to do with getting SVN status from slow remote servers (using Subclipse 1.0.4).

Eclipse SDK

Version: 3.2.1
Build id: M20060921-0945
Eclipse SDK

(In reply to comment #1)
> Happens for me too, but seems to be avoidable by switching to e.g. the Outline
> view before quitting Eclipse; leaving the Package Explorer view selected on
> quit recreates this bug on startup every time. It is not necessary to close
> editor tabs.
> 
> "Initializing Java tooling" is slow (>30 seconds) when this bug has not been
> triggered, with only a small number of repositories, but 5 of those are remote;
> my feeling is that this is something to do with getting SVN status from slow
> remote servers (using Subclipse 1.0.4).

> Eclipse SDK

> Version: 3.2.1
> Build id: M20060921-0945
> Eclipse SDK
> 

Indeed this is another solution, i can avoid it by switching to "J2EE prespective" before quitting. The problem is being reproduced if i quit while in "Java prespective".

Another thing i 've noticed is that the problem occurs for one specific project only, in my case. I have more projects created at the same time and this is not happening with any of them, allthough these were created recently and the problem existed even before this.
There are numerous packages and classes involved with that one.
Sorry I just stumbled on this bug while reviewing my bug list. This appears to be a WTP/JEM issue, so I will assign this to the correct product/component.
*** Bug 171772 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Carl - we may need to look at early startup detection policies in
FlexibleProjectContainer.computeClasspathEntries()

If the EMF/ModuleCore facilities are not available yet - we should short circuit this call, and make sure its initialized later....
Until we have a viable solution or patch, I'm untargetting this defect.
